title: Make the Cards in the /sheets screen buttons
body:
## Refactoring Cards as Buttons in the /Sheets Screen

### Objective:

Transform the cards in the /Sheets screen into buttons, replacing the current implementation that relies on div elements and onClick handlers. Additionally, ensure that the Sheets screen becomes keyboard-navigable for enhanced accessibility.

### Specifications:

1. **Card-to-Button Transformation:**
   - Replace the existing div elements used for cards with button elements.

2. **Button Appearance:**
   - Style the buttons to maintain the visual design consistency of the cards. This may include background colors, borders, and typography.

3. **Accessibility:**
   - Implement appropriate ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes to ensure the buttons are fully accessible to screen readers and assistive technologies.

4. **Keyboard Navigation:**
   - Ensure that users can navigate through the buttons using keyboard controls.
     - Users should be able to use the "Tab" key to move between buttons.
     - Users should be able to activate the currently focused button by pressing the "Enter" key.
     - Ensure a clear visual indicator (e.g., focus ring) for the active button.
     
5. **Focus Management:**
   - Implement focus management to prevent users from getting trapped in the buttons loop.
     - When the last button is focused and the user presses "Tab," focus should move to the next interactive element (e.g., links or form inputs).

6. **OnClick Functionality:**
   - If the cards had onClick functionality, ensure that this functionality is preserved when the buttons are clicked.

7. **Testing and QA:**
   - Thoroughly test the button implementation to ensure that it performs equivalently to the previous div-based cards.
   - Verify that keyboard navigation works as expected.

title: [BUG] Move config.py file to the root folder and update references
body:
Currently, the config.py file is located in the src folder of our repository. In order to improve the organization and accessibility of our codebase, we propose moving the config.py file to the root folder of the repository.

This enhancement involves updating all the programs that currently reference the config.py file to read from the new location.

Tasks:
1. Move the config.py file from the src folder to the root folder of the repository.
2. Identify all the programs that use the config.py file.
3. Modify each program to read from the new location of the config.py file.
4. Test the modified programs to ensure they function correctly with the updated file location.

Expected Outcome:
By moving the config.py file to the root folder and updating the references in the programs, we will improve the organization of our codebase and make it easier to locate and manage the configuration file.

title: Darken scroll bars in dark mode
body:
In #1337 the custom scroll bars were removed for accessibility, but now they look starkly bright again in dark mode, and really cut the primary navbar away from the main content. 

https://stackoverflow.com/a/66097469 shows a happy medium: setting `color-scheme: dark` when the dark theme is selected will fix the scroll bar coloring (and presumably other browser-default things, like unstyled input elements maybe). 

I don't know scss enough to propose a diff but hopefully this is easy for someone?

title: Iteration plan for version 1.0.0
body:
- [ ] **User Interface and Functionality:**
  - [ ] **Automatic URL Recognition:**
    Automatically make URLs clickable in text fields.
  - [ ] **Simple Navigation:**
    Keep navigation simple and intuitive with clear menus and buttons.
  - [ ] **Favorites/Favorites List:**
    Allow users to save and manage their favorite bypassed links.
  - [ ] **Feedback Form:**
    Add an easily accessible feedback form for users to share their opinions.
  - [ ] **Search Functionality:**
    Implement a search bar to allow users to search through bypassed links.
  - [ ] **Contextual Help:**
    Provide contextual help information to users, such as tooltips and help buttons.
  - [ ] **Responsive Design:**
    Ensure the website works well on both desktops and mobile devices.
  - [ ] **Social Media Sharing:**
    Allow users to share bypassed links on social media platforms.
  - [ ] **Print-Friendly Pages:**
    Optimize pages for printing by removing unnecessary elements.
  - [ ] **User Preferences:**
    Allow users to save preferences, such as theme and language settings.
  - [ ] **Visible Link Status:**
    Indicate when a bypassed link has been generated and is available for use.
  - [ ] **Suggested Popular Websites:**
    Provide suggestions for popular websites frequently bypassed by other users.
  - [ ] **Secure SSL Connection:**
    Ensure a secure HTTPS connection for data encryption.
  - [ ] **Cookie Management:**
    Provide clear information about cookie usage and offer cookie management options.
  - [ ] **User Statistics:**
    Offer users insights into their activities, such as the number of generated bypassed links.
  - [ ] **Optimized Loading Speed:**
    Optimize the website for fast loading times, especially on mobile devices.
  - [ ] **Live Chat Support:**
    Integrate a live chat feature for immediate user support.
  - [ ] **Accessibility Features:**
    Provide accessibility features, such as screen reader support and high-contrast colors.
  - [ ] **Session Inactivity Warning:**
    Display a warning when the session is about to expire due to inactivity.
  - [ ] **Customizable Themes:**
    Allow users to choose from different themes for a personalized experience.
  - [ ] **Notification System:**
    Implement a notification system to alert users of important updates.
  - [ ] **Browser Compatibility:**
    Ensure compatibility with various web browsers for a seamless user experience.
  - [ ] **Keyboard Shortcuts:**
    Provide keyboard shortcuts for efficient navigation and actions.
  - [ ] **Adaptive Content Layout:**
    Create a responsive layout that adapts to different screen sizes and orientations.
  - [ ] **In-Page Editing:**
    Enable users to edit content directly on the page for customization.
  - [ ] **Integrated Analytics:**
    Integrate analytics tools to track user interactions and improve the service.
  - [ ] **Multi-Language Support:**
    Support multiple languages to cater to a diverse user base.
  - [ ] **User Surveys:**
    Conduct user surveys to gather feedback and enhance user satisfaction.
  - [ ] **Geo-Location Services:**
    Offer location-based services for personalized content and recommendations.
  - [ ] **Data Privacy Compliance:**
    Ensure compliance with data privacy regulations and provide transparent policies.
  - [ ] **Video Tutorials:**
    Create video tutorials to guide users on using the website effectively.
  - [ ] **Customizable Notifications:**
    Allow users to customize the types of notifications they receive.
  - [ ] **Interactive Widgets:**
    Include interactive widgets for engaging user experiences.
  - [ ] **Gamification Elements:**
    Add gamification elements to encourage user participation and loyalty.
  - [ ] **API Integration:**
    Integrate with external APIs to enhance functionality and content offerings.
  - [ ] **User-Generated Content:**
    Enable users to contribute content, such as reviews and recommendations.
  - [ ] **Polls and Surveys:**
    Conduct polls and surveys to gather opinions and preferences from users.
  - [ ] **Collaborative Features:**
    Implement collaborative features for shared projects and content creation.
  - [ ] **Augmented Reality Support:**
    Explore augmented reality features for innovative user interactions.
  - [ ] **Offline Mode:**
    Allow users to access certain features and content even when offline.
  - [ ] **Browser Extensions:**
    Develop browser extensions for seamless integration with users' web browsers.
  - [ ] **Social Media Login:**
    Enable users to log in or sign up using their social media accounts.
  - [ ] **Content Moderation:**
    Implement content moderation tools to ensure a safe and respectful community.
  - [ ] **Dynamic Content Loading:**
    Load content dynamically as users scroll for a smoother browsing experience.

title: Add Table of Contents to README
body:
### Description:
Currently, the README file lacks a table of contents, which can make it challenging for users and contributors to quickly navigate and find relevant information. Adding a table of contents would improve the documentation's usability and accessibility.

### Proposed Changes:
- Add a table of contents to the README file.
- Organize the table of contents to provide an overview of the document's sections and subsections.
- Ensure that links in the table of contents are properly formatted and lead to the corresponding sections within the document.

### Acceptance Criteria:
- The README file should include a well-structured table of contents.
- Each item in the table of contents should link to the appropriate section within the README.
- The table of contents should be kept up-to-date as the document evolves.

### Additional Information:
- If there are any specific guidelines or preferences for the table of contents format or styling, please specify them here.
- If you need assistance or have any questions while working on this issue, feel free to ask for help in the comments.

`Background and foreground colors do not have a sufficient contrast ratio.` Fix this accessibility bug without changing the website theme. Only use Tailwind CSS for styling and also do not use global styling for this project.

title: [Feature request] : Implement Dark Mode
body:
Problem:
As of now, our application does not offer a dark mode option. Dark mode has become a popular feature, providing users with a visually pleasing and energy-efficient alternative to the default light mode.

Request:
We would like to implement dark mode to enhance the user experience and give users the flexibility to choose their preferred mode.

Implementation Steps:
To achieve dark mode, we'll need to:

Design Dark Mode UI: Create a visually appealing dark mode UI that complements our app's aesthetics.

Toggle Switch: Add a user-friendly toggle switch or button that allows users to switch between light and dark modes (in the header)

Adjust Colors: Modify the color schemes, text, and background colors to align with the dark mode design.

Accessibility: Ensure that the dark mode is accessible and maintains readability and usability for all users.

I'm searching for a developer who has practical experience in creating dark mode features.

title: Add Accessibility Scanning to Cypress Test Suite
body: Add a tool like [cypress-axe](https://github.com/component-driven/cypress-axe) or [cypress-audit](https://github.com/mfrachet/cypress-audit) to the Cypress setup in order to perform automated accessbility testing upon the application.

title: Enhance Select component accessibility
body: `src/components/ui/select.tsx`

title: [BUG] : The `img` elements do not have `height` and `width` attributes.
body:
**Describe the bug**
The `img` elements do not have `height` and `width` attributes.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open website
2. Open dev tools
3. Click on lighthouse
4. Measure lighthouse score
5. See accessibility error

**Expected behavior**
All the `img` elements  must have `height` and `width` attributes.

**Screenshots**

![Screenshot (1471)](https://github.com/SudhansuuRanjan/tesla-nitp-web/assets/77230416/ae58417e-f57f-4612-a52d-3d0951b01e83)

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
OS: Windows
Browser : Chrome

**Additional context**
You can refer to the following [docs](https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_img.asp) for more info on img attributes.

title: [BUG] :  Buttons do not have an accessible name
body:
**Describe the bug**

Buttons do not have an accessible name

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open website 
2. Open dev tools 
3. Click on lighthouse
4. Measure lighthouse score
5. See accessibility error

**Expected behavior**
All the buttons should have an accessible names.

**Screenshots**
![Screenshot (1470)](https://github.com/SudhansuuRanjan/tesla-nitp-web/assets/77230416/11595a2a-e50f-4a47-9019-5e5e23c08e5f)


**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows
 - Browser : Chrome

**Additional context**
You can refer to the following [docs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Roles/button_role) for more info on accessible buttons.

title: Make Signup Page Responsive
body:
**Title:** Make Signup Page Responsive

**Description:**
This GitHub issue addresses the need to make the signup page responsive, ensuring that it adapts well to various screen sizes and devices. A responsive design enhances user experience, allowing users to access and interact with the signup page comfortably on different devices, such as desktops, tablets, and smartphones.

**Tasks:**
1. **Responsive Styling:** 
   - [ ] Modify the styling of the signup page components to ensure they adjust gracefully to different screen sizes.
   - [ ] Ensure that the layout and content of the page are visually appealing and functional on both large screens and smaller devices.

2. **Media Queries:** 
   - [ ] Implement CSS media queries to apply specific styles based on screen width breakpoints.
   - [ ] Create responsive breakpoints for common device sizes, such as mobile phones, tablets, and desktop screens.

3. **Testing:** 
   - [ ] Thoroughly test the responsiveness of the signup page on various devices and screen sizes.
   - [ ] Verify that all page elements, including text, forms, and buttons, are accessible and user-friendly.

4. **User Experience:** 
   - [ ] Ensure that the user experience is consistent and comfortable, regardless of the device used to access the signup page.
   - [ ] Validate that all interactive elements remain functional and easy to use on smaller screens.

**Additional Information:**
- A responsive signup page enhances user accessibility and ensures that users can create accounts from any device, contributing to a positive user experience.
- Careful styling and testing are crucial to achieve a seamless responsive design.

Upon successful completion of this issue, the signup page will be responsive, providing an optimal user experience on various screen sizes and devices.

title: [FEATURE] Create Card Component
body:
### Description
Create a card component using storybook. Do research on typical horizontal card styling (height, width, padding,..) by checking out common frameworks like [MUI](https://mui.com/material-ui/) or Bootstrap.

![card](https://github.com/YurisCodingClub/accessibility-mentor/assets/54622834/56a07b48-a8a9-458c-94a7-1d6f3cd3b783)

### Additional links
Official docs from storybook https://storybook.js.org/

```[tasklist]
### Tasks
- [ ] Creade card component
- [ ] Use dummy image and text
```

title: TextToSpeech
body:
Dear Reviewer,

I hope this message finds you well. I have submitted a pull request,
I am pleased to submit this pull request that introduces a Text-to-Speech (TTS) feature to the app, enhancing its functionality and accessibility. This significant improvement allows users to convert written text into spoken words, making the content audible and accessible to a wider audience.

Thank you for your time and consideration.
Best regards,

title: The "resend" button in the verification code screen must be bolded, if not underlined (plus one more)
body: ## Describe the bug / expected behavior The "resend" button in the verification code screen must be bolded, if not underlined. Texts that only differ in their font colors create an accessibility issue. ## What are the steps to reproduce? I didn't run the code myself, but I noticed this in the PR description of #287 ## Screenshots / Screen recording This is React: This is React Native, as of #287 ![image](https://github.com/etn-ccis/blui-react-native-workflows/assets/8997218/99651058-61a8-4801-8c03-2f349e29b7f7) ## Suggested fix Just use an inline style overwrite ## Anything else to add? **Also, notice the difference in the wording** — React says "Didn't receive an email?" while React Native says "Didn't receive a code?" Design-wise I am fine with either way, but I do believe they should be consistent by default. If you can address this parity in the same PR it would be awesome.

### Guidelines 👇🏼

title: [Feature request] : Implement Dark Mode
body:
Problem:
As of now, our application does not offer a dark mode option. Dark mode has become a popular feature, providing users with a visually pleasing and energy-efficient alternative to the default light mode.

Request:
We would like to implement dark mode to enhance the user experience and give users the flexibility to choose their preferred mode.

Implementation Steps:
To achieve dark mode, we'll need to:

Design Dark Mode UI: Create a visually appealing dark mode UI that complements our app's aesthetics.

Toggle Switch: Add a user-friendly toggle switch or button that allows users to switch between light and dark modes (in the header)

Adjust Colors: Modify the color schemes, text, and background colors to align with the dark mode design.

Accessibility: Ensure that the dark mode is accessible and maintains readability and usability for all users.

title: URL Validator Python Script 🌐✅
body:
**Objective**:
Develop a Python script that checks if a given URL is valid and accessible. This tool will help users verify the correctness of URLs.

**Features**:

1. **URL Validation**:
   - Implement a function to validate the format and structure of a URL.
   - for example: https://example.com -> is valid , htt://data.com -> invalid

2. **Accessibility Check**:
   - Verify if the URL is reachable and returns a valid HTTP response.

3. **User-Friendly Output**:
   - Provide clear feedback on the validity and accessibility of the URL.

**Example Usage**:

```python
# Example usage of the URL validator script
import url_validator

url = "https://www.example.com"
is_valid, is_accessible = url_validator.validate(url)

if is_valid:
    print("The URL is valid.")
    
    if is_accessible:
        print("The URL is accessible.")
    else:
        print("The URL is not accessible.")
else:
    print("The URL is not valid.")
```

**Difficulty**: Beginner/Intermediate
**Tags**: Python, URL Validation, Accessibility, HTTP Requests

**Additional Information**:
- Familiarity with URL structure and basic Python programming is recommended for contributors interested in this task.
- Consider using the `requests` library for making HTTP requests to verify URL accessibility.

title: a way to convert glyphs back into name
body:
### what
a way to convert glyphs back into name

### use cases
* super helpful in migration from breaking changes in glyph designation like in #58 
* documentation or tutorial material where showing names make more sense 


e.g. for "showing names more sensible":
* recommended font [dejavu] not suitable or not to the liking - say for print media like books
* in a beginner tutorial - where you are introducing this language to newcomers & you _want_ to start with names
* in accessibility critical usage: i.e. for people with eye sight problems
* where you (content creator/book author) can't expect reader to remember specifics of any language as you are covering huge breadth of prog langs/paradigms
* better searchability of keywords

[dejavu]: https://www.uiua.org/docs/install

title: Text size on small devices
body:
**Issue: Increase Text Size on Small Devices**

**Description:**
The current text size on the website is too small on small devices, making it challenging for users to read and interact with the content comfortably. To enhance the user experience, we need to increase the text size for small screens.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Access the website on a small mobile device or emulator.
2. Observe the text size, including headings, paragraphs, and navigation menus.

**Expected Behavior:**
Text should be legible and easily readable on small screens without the need for users to zoom in or strain their eyes. The increased text size should provide a more user-friendly experience.

**Priority:** Medium

**Tasks:**
- Review the current typography settings and CSS styles.
- Determine an appropriate font size and line height for text elements on small screens.
- Ensure that headings, paragraphs, and other critical text elements are adequately sized for mobile users.
- Update the CSS styles to reflect the increased text size.
- Test the changes on various small devices to verify improved readability.
- Consider responsive design principles to maintain a harmonious layout while adjusting the text size.

**Additional Information:**
- This improvement is essential for improving the overall usability and accessibility of the website on mobile devices.
- Ensure that the changes are consistent with the website's design and branding guidelines.

title: BUG: Fix All warnings in "Accessibility" category
body:
## Description 
 We would like to fix all the remaining lint issues on Oppia Android in "Accessibility" category.

## Steps To Reproduce
Run the following command from a terminal in a checked-out Oppia Android repo:

`./gradlew :app:lint`

Output:  All warnings in "Accessibility" category

Under this category, the warnings are mainly of 3 types.

**Warning: Image without contentDescription.**
Fix: Add a contentDescription to each of those ImageView, or android:importantForAccessibility="no" for views that are safe to ignore.

**Warning: 'onTouch' lambda should call 'View#performClick' when a click is detected**
Fix: Call customView.performClick( ).

**Warning: 'clickable' attribute found, please also add 'focusable'.**
Fix: Set android:focusable="true" to allow keyboard navigation per: https://android.googlesource.com/platform/tools/base/+/studio-master-dev/lint/libs/lint-checks/src/main/java/com/android/tools/lint/checks/KeyboardNavigationDetector.java?autodive=0%2F.

## Expected Behavior
Running the command above should not show any errors.

title: [FEATURE] GitHub Button and Dark Mode Toggle in Navbar
body:
### Description

 In the current project, we lack two essential features that can significantly enhance the user experience and accessibility. This proposal suggests the addition of a GitHub button and a Dark Mode toggle button.

### GitHub Button

The absence of a GitHub button in the project's navigation bar hinders users' ability to easily navigate to the GitHub repository associated with the project. This button should be prominently placed, allowing users to seamlessly access the GitHub page where they can contribute, start the project, or explore the codebase.

### Dark Mode Toggle

Furthermore, introducing a Dark Mode toggle button would cater to users who prefer a darker interface for various reasons, including reducing eye strain during nighttime use. This feature can improve accessibility and make the project more user-friendly.

By implementing these two features, we can enhance the overall user experience and engagement with the project. Users will find it easier to engage with the community, contribute to the project, and customize their viewing experience.

title: [on hold] events model + html rendering
body: this is what a few sample events look like on nyc-noise.com: --- there are many parts to an event listing :-) and we want to recreate the main parts for now, both in the model (i.e. the database) and in the html template/rendering. task: create the relevant fields in the model, as well as a sub-template that will be included from the homepage and other pages (see #36) to render a single event. --- an event model should include the following: - (we are skipping the accessibility icons for now -- we'll discuss/see how to go about them once venues are imported) - optional "bracket" content i.e. `[OUTDOORS!]` that sometimes appears at the very beginning. - datetime - it would be great if the admin defaulted to new york time. we do however (definitely) want to keep the underlying database/project datetime to be utc. - presenter/title - this is the part that comes after the hour and is not bold - artists (this will link to the main hyperlink -- see below) - main hyperlink to the concert/tickets - optional (either render an `` or don't if there's no link) - potentially a second link name + url - "@" character followed by the venue name + address. we can start with the venue name only for now, and as our models become more complicated / we import the venues (see #15) we'll add more stuff here - optional "tiny extra text" - tiny extra text - optional entire override -- this should be a field (which should rich text -- see #10) which allows Jessica to entirely override the whole event text. this is the escape hatch :-)

title: Update index.js
body:
The code has undergone several enhancements:

Routing Implementation:

Integrated BrowserRouter and Route components from the 'react-router-dom' library to enable multi-page navigation within the application. Added route definitions using Route components within a Switch, allowing different components to render based on the URL path. Additional Routes and Components:

Introduced an 'About' page by defining a new functional component called About to display specific content when the '/about' route is accessed. Created a 'Not Found' component named NotFound to handle 404 errors, rendering a message when a URL doesn't match any defined routes. Optimized Rendering and Theme Setup:

Utilized the ReactDOM.render method to directly render the ImprovedApp component, simplifying the application setup. Configured Chakra UI's ChakraProvider with an extended theme that includes color and font settings. Also included a ColorModeScript for improved initial color mode handling for better accessibility. These changes have transformed the code into a more comprehensive and functional React application with enhanced navigation capabilities, distinct pages for various routes, and an optimized rendering structure with improved theming setup through Chakra UI's functionalities.

title: `no_magic_numbers` doesnt work with tuple destructuring
body:
### New Issue Checklist

- [x] Updated SwiftLint to the latest version
- [x] I searched for [existing GitHub issues](https://github.com/realm/SwiftLint/issues)

### Describe the bug

code like
```swift
let (httpStatusCodeErrorLowerBound, httpStatusCodeErrorUpperBound) = (400, 599)
```
still reports
`No Magic Numbers Violation: Magic numbers should be replaced by named constants (no_magic_numbers)`
while similar code
```swift
let httpStatusCodeErrorLowerBound = 400
let httpStatusCodeErrorUpperBound = 599

title: [Feature] - Add more beginner friendly accessibility questions
body:
### What feature would you like to see?

### What general issue would you like to create?

[developerquiz.org](developerquiz.org) currently has over 1200+ quiz questions. 

We are looking to expand the beginner accessibility questions and we encourage other developers to add their quiz questions to the site.

Example of beginner friendly accessibility questions we are looking for.

- what are landmarks, 
- layout structure, 
- min color contrast, 
- min font-size, 
- semantic HTML, 
- labels, buttons, 

You can find the complete list of accessibility questions below.
https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/Developer_Quiz_Site/blob/main/src/data/accessibility-quiz.ts

You can add your own questions to the top of that file.
**Please first check to make sure your question doesn't already exist before creating a PR.**

Here is the correct format for the questions. 
The distractors represent the incorrect answers. 

```
 {
    Question: "What is web accessibility?",
    Answer: "the practice of building websites that are usable by everyone",
    Distractor1: "a new JavaScript framework",
    Distractor2: "a sorting algorithm",
    Distractor3: "a type of programming paradigm",
    Explanation:
      "Web accessibility means building websites that are usable by as many people as possible.",
    Link: "https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/what-is-website-accessibility-18ce00ec990f/",
  },
```
For the `link` field, please make sure to use a freeCodeCamp article, freeCodeCamp YouTube video or [W3C content](https://www.w3.org/WAI/).

If you choose to reference a video, please make sure to include the timestamp for the topic covered.


You can read more about how to create timestamps in this [helpful article](https://www.lifewire.com/link-to-specific-part-of-youtube-video-1616414#). 

There are plenty of freeCodeCamp news articles to pull accessibility questions from:
https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/common-accessibility-errors-and-how-to-fix-them/
https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/web-accessibility-best-practices-a11y-tips/
https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/accessibility-testing-tools-for-ada-compliance/
https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/what-is-website-accessibility-18ce00ec990f/
https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/4-principles-for-getting-started-with-website-accessibility-4e85f75730b/

**This issue will not be assigned to anyone and will remain open for multiple contributors.**
**Please do not close this issue**

Happy contributing!

title: data sources monthly digest email
body:
### Context
We have mailgun set up for the password reset workflow. We should use that to make a monthly email to anyone who chooses to subscribe. The logic should be to use all data sources from the API that are edited within the last month, but in the future we will have parameters—for example, people can subscribe to updates _for a specific search_ of data sources.

## Requirements
- requires https://github.com/Police-Data-Accessibility-Project/data-sources-app/issues/419
- [ ] get an API key from PDAP
- [ ] create a script which hits our API and sends a Mailgun email with the below contents
- [ ] test the script with your own Mailgun API key (free)
   - when you submit, include the test results
- [ ] PDAP staff will set up the automation with Jenkins, our pipeline
- [ ] The script should use environment variables: `SECRET_KEY` for the API key and `MAILGUN_KEY` for Mailgun.

### Email Contents
>New data sources: `number of rows`
>Updates to existing sources: `number of rows`
>Number of agencies affected by new/updated sources: `number of agencies`
>Explore the data at https://pdap.io/data

### Email Recipients
`operations@pdap.io`

### Email Frequency
Monthly, on the first at 12pm (noon) ET.

title: Create User Profile Section✨
body:
Issue:
We want to create a User Profile section in our web application to enhance user experience and provide essential information about each user. This section will display the user's role, name, and their profile photo.

Proposed Solution:

**User Profile Section:**

- Implement a dedicated User Profile section within the user account dashboard.
- Display the user's role (e.g., "Admin," "Teacher," "Student," etc.) to indicate their permissions and responsibilities.
- Show the user's name, making it more personal and identifiable.
- Allow users to upload and display a profile photo/avatar.

title: 📚 Documentation: Tutorials page skips from <h2> to <h4> [a11y][TheA11y100]
body:
### 💭 Description

## Issue
On the tutorials page the heading levels skip from `<h2>` to `<h4>`.

![Headings Map showing skipped heading levels from h2 to h4](https://github.com/appwrite/website/assets/121672086/e4629ffe-44e7-4dad-beeb-2c144db60277)

## Why it matters
People using assistive technology rely on proper headings structure to navigate effectively. By skipping levels people can get lost or miss entire sections of content using assistive tech.

## Suggested fix
Two options here: first is to change the `<h4>` on each card to a `<h3>`.

However there is also a `<h2>` called "client" which is not currently needed / is redundant. **A better option** may be to remove this `<h2>` and promote the current cards' `<h4>`s to `<h2>`s as this will be a more logical structure for the page.

![screenshot of current page with a heading level 2 called "client" and then heading level 4s for each item](https://github.com/appwrite/website/assets/121672086/30a0183f-9eef-435b-a907-447a29df772c)

## Relevant Success Criterion WCAG
[Info and Relationships in WCAG](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/info-and-relationships)
[Technique using heading levels](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Techniques/html/H42)

## Additional Notes
Good first issue, but needs input from Appwrite to which solution they would prefer.

[Found on stream on 2023-10-25](https://www.twitch.tv/videos/1959992199)

### 👀 Have you spent some time to check if this issue has been raised before?

- [X] I checked and didn't find similar issue

### 🏢 Have you read the Code of Conduct?

- [X] I have read the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/appwrite/.github/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

title: Table Block
body:
# User story

As an editor,
I want a table block in the CMS,
so that I can add tabular data to any page.

As a website visitor,
I want tabular data to be easily accessible,
so that I can quickly read / scan it.

# System design

- Use [DatoCMS Table Editor plugin](https://www.datocms.com/marketplace/plugins/i/datocms-plugin-table-editor) for a convenient editor experience of the `table` data.
- Add an optional `title` that can be used as `<caption>` for improved accessibility.
- Add basic styling so they table has good responsive behaviour (see [CSS-Tricks: A table with both a sticky header and a sticky first column](https://css-tricks.com/a-table-with-both-a-sticky-header-and-a-sticky-first-column/) and [CSS-Tricks: Responsive data tables](https://css-tricks.com/responsive-data-tables/) for well thought out approaches).
- Supports being used in both modular content and structured text

## Content model

**Table Block**

- `title`: string (single-line), optional
- `table`: json (table plugin), required

title: feat: make social anchors accessible on footer ✨
body:
## Description
- The feature is about to improve the accessibility of Coffee Bean Website's Footer section
- I'm going to add important attributes like `aria-label` for social anchors (links like Github) which are placed on Social media section.

- it is important to note that we want to add the `title` attribute also. This is because the `title` attribute is intended to provide additional information to screen reader users.

- The `aria-label` attribute is a way more important for providing accessibility information to screen reader users. The `aria-label` attribute is an Accessible Rich Internet Applications (ARIA) attribute that can be used to provide a label for an element. This label is then read aloud by screen readers, providing additional information about the element to the user.

- In general, the `aria-label` & `title` attributes are preferred for providing accessibility information to screen reader users.

- You can consider to assign this issue to me to make the site accessible for screen readers

## Screenshots (Changes are going to made for these elements)

![image](https://github.com/yash19sinha/coffee-bean/assets/92252895/d1fea804-957b-4fda-ab5d-054952ee4352)


## Additional context

- I'm a **Hacktoberfest23** Contributor

Given it was such a short timeline, having the fix be beta tested more was more important than this refactor. As a follow-up, there's some refactoring we could do to improve the `getNodeText` implementation from https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/pull/54902

2. Add unit tests to verify the correct functionality

title: Analyze the Top 10 React Libraries for UI Components
body:
Greetings, information seekers! WebCrumbs aims to make UI building a breeze. Your mission is to investigate what the top React libraries are doing right.

**What Needs to Be Done?**

- Identify the top 10 React libraries focused on UI components.
- Analyze their pros, cons, and unique features.
- Compile your findings in a markdown file.
- Open a pull request to add this research into our `Research/` directory.

**Why Is This Important?**

- Helps us understand what users appreciate in existing solutions.
- Informs our own approach to UI component building.

**Skills Needed**

- A general understanding of UI/UX principles.
- Research skills to evaluate libraries based on merit.

Eager to scope out the landscape? Navigate to our [WebCrumbs GitHub repo](https://github.com/webcrumbs-community/webcrumbs) and share your insights!

title: Give textinput a label
body:
**Description:**
The textinput should have a label with instructions which is always visible to pass [WCAG 3.3.2 Labels](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#labels-or-instructions). At the moment we use the placeholder text, which is probably fine for our target audience, but failing level A of WCAG would be unfortunate.
Maybe we could have a label which is fixed to the top of the textinput like in the second screenshot below. Not sure what it could say, would love to hear some ideas. 

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- There is a label associated with the chatbox textinput, which doesn't go away when we type with the bot.

title: Core: New Reference Asset - Image
body:
An image asset should be added as a reference asset that will allow users to upload relevant images to complement or enhance text. An image asset should be able to have an optional placeholder tag and an optional caption incase users want to provide text with that image.

## Requirements

- An image asset should have a metaData,  

> - Which should include a ref to the image . 

> - As well as an optional accessibility , which will be a string for accessibility support.

- An image asset should have an optional placeholder text.

> - The placeholder is a string

- An image asset should have an optional caption text, if a caption needs to be displayed along with the image. 

> - This caption should be an asset


 
At its simplest case, this JSON should render an image
```
    {
      "id": "image-1",
      "type": "image",
      "metaData": {
        "ref": "https://player-ui.github.io/latest/logo/logo-dark-large.png"
      }
    }
``` 


## Execution:

Add mocks to the [mocks](https://github.com/player-ui/player/tree/main/plugins/reference-assets/mocks) package to show the optional fields and show all implementations for rendering.

title: [Improvement]: Generate manpage with `clap-mangen` for `cargo-shuttle`
body:
### Describe the improvement

We use [`clap`](https://crates.io/crates/clap) for parsing the command-line arguments for `cargo-shuttle`. We can also integrate [`clap-mangen`](https://crates.io/crates/clap-mangen) for generating a manpage. I see two ways of doing this:

- have a separate binary (`cargo-shuttle-mangen`) (see [this](https://github.com/orhun/halp/blob/main/src/bin/mangen.rs) example)
- use the build script (see [this](https://github.com/orhun/kmon/blob/master/build.rs) example)

Here's why having a manpage is good:

> Having a man page is advantageous because it serves as local and offline documentation for commands or programs, offering users quick and standardized access to crucial information. Its consistency, comprehensive details, and integration with the command line make it a valuable resource for understanding and utilizing software effectively. The accessibility of man pages promotes inclusivity and facilitates scripting and automation, contributing to an enhanced user experience in various computing environments.


### Duplicate declaration

- [X] I have searched the issues and this improvement has not been requested before.

title: Question: time can have a name from author?
body:
This came up because i'm looking at what HTML elements can (only) be named from author / need wpt tests, and the naming expectations for `<time>` vs `role=time` weren't as I would have initially thought, being the time element is a text-level semantic, and those largely aren't meant to be named.

Curious about the wg's thoughts on `time` being a namable role from authors.  While browsers expose the name, VO on macOS and Narrator with Edge (specifically if using Narrator key + left/right arrows to navigate) are really the only ones that effectively expose the name - unless the element is made focusable.  And then that's a weird hodgepodge of the name sometimes being announced but the role often not... but also, why would anyone be making a time element focusable?

I am not sure what need there is for a time role/element to be named.  is this something that should remain / AT have bugs filed to work out UX?  Or is this something that maybe shouldn't be named and it can be removed w/out much in the way of anyone noticing?

title: Update README to Reflect Project-Specific Information
body:
**Title: Update README to Reflect Project-Specific Information**

**Issue:**

The current README.md file in the project repository is the default template provided by React.js. It needs to be updated to accurately represent the features, setup instructions, and guidelines specific to our Password Generator project.

**Description:**

The README file plays a crucial role in providing users and contributors with essential information about our Password Generator application. The current content lacks project-specific details, including the features, setup instructions, and contribution guidelines.

This issue aims to update the README file with the following key information:

1. **Features:** Highlight the unique features of our Password Generator, such as password customization options, password history, clipboard functionality, and history management.

2. **Getting Started:** Provide clear and comprehensive steps for users to clone the repository, install dependencies, and run the application locally.

3. **Contribution Guide:** Clearly outline the contribution process, including forking the repository, creating branches, and submitting pull requests. It should also direct contributors to review our Contributing Guidelines and Code of Conduct for a smooth collaboration.

4. **License Information:** Retain or update details regarding the project's license (MIT License) to ensure legal compliance.

**Tasks:**

- Review the existing README file.
- Update the file with project-specific details, including Features, Getting Started, Contributing, and License sections.
- Ensure clarity and accuracy in the instructions provided.

**Additional Notes:**

The updated README file will not only guide users on using the Password Generator but also encourage community engagement through contributions while maintaining compliance with our project's licensing terms.

**Assigned:** @baliramStrikes 

**Labels:**
- documentation
- help wanted
- good first issue (if appropriate for newcomers)

The revised README will serve as a clear guide for users and potential contributors, enhancing the overall accessibility and understanding of our Password Generator project.

Extension version: 0.3.2023110115 VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.85.0-insider (e55009850900a64eeb37b2228c79855ceff63914, 2023-11-03T15:11:12.179Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22621 Modes:

title: [Accessibility] The map feedback link has a wrong `aria-label` attribute
body: Hi Team, Version: v3.0.0-beta.5 I've scanned a few pages with mapbox-gl-js with the AXE tool and ran into an accessibility issue with the latest version. It's marked as serious, but visible only if you turn on an experimental feature. Issue name: Elements must have their visible text as part of their accessible name More informations about this types of issues: https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.8/label-content-name-mismatch Fix for this issue is quite simple: either the link shouldn't have an `aria-label` attribute because the text inside the link is self explanatory or the text in `aria-label` attribute should start with `Improve this map`. I guess the first option is easier and better. Element with the issue: ```html Improve this map ``` ![Screenshot from 2023-11-03 21-56-04](https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-gl-js/assets/891497/d97363d4-3698-450b-86fe-7898d4a2f580)

title: Error indicator on span in /Traces is hard to see in dark mode
body:
The contrast between the red and the dark background doesn't meet accessibility standards, which might be ok if we could rely on the shape as well. But the outer shape is always a circle and the inner shape is hard to tell also, in part because of the size and in part because of the contrast:

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/assets/9613109/80ad73cb-96fc-4db1-a493-9fa954229b7b)

It's a little better in light mode since the red/white contrast is better, but the shape of the indicator in the circle is still hard to see unless it is big enough:

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/assets/9613109/9795913f-7032-427d-b272-9a984311ddf1)

This isn't _just_ an a11y issue since it is hard to tell what the icon is at 100% scaling, but accessibility is definitely a part of how we'd address it.

A few thoughts:
1. We should see if we can adjust the icon in some way to make it easier to decipher (use regular instead of filled? use Size16 instead?). If not, we should consider if there's a different way to display that information
2. These individual blocks _could_ be light-colored even if in dark mode (see screenshot below) if we wanted to keep the error red the same. But we should also see about trying to make an error red color that works better on the dark background across the site.

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/assets/9613109/24f52ac5-fd45-41ba-a487-c794b8271e77)

title: Mark required configuration parameters as mandatory in the right side panel
body:
### Please describe the feature that you want to propose

The camel catalog provides information about parameters being optional or mandatory via the attribute `required`. We should indicate mandatory parameters (`"required": true`) in the configuration panel and as a second iteration if these fields are not filled they should be marked as in error. (either via a status icon on the input field or by using other means like a red background color in the input field, which might be not ideal in terms of accessibility)

title: [BUG] AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'content'
body:
### Required prerequisites

- [X] I have read the documentation <https://camel-ai.github.io/camel/camel.html>.
- [X] I have searched the [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/issues) and [Discussions](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions) that this hasn't already been reported. (+1 or comment there if it has.)
- [X] Consider asking first in a [Discussion](https://github.com/camel-ai/camel/discussions/new).

### What version of camel are you using?

0.1.0

### System information

Default colab environment

### Problem description

I am trying to run the [colab demo](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1AzP33O8rnMW__7ocWJhVBXjKziJXPtim?usp=sharing) of your repo, but encountering the following error:
```
Original task prompt:
Design a custom game using pygame

Specified task prompt:
Design a real-time virtual reality game that combines elements of puzzle-solving and exploration. The Computer Programmer will develop complex algorithms to render detailed 3D environments, manage player interactions, and create realistic physics simulations. The game will challenge gamers to solve intricate puzzles while uncovering hidden treasures in a visually stunning virtual world.

AI User:

Instruction: Design the main character for the game.
Input: None



AI Assistant:

Solution: To design the main character for the game, we need to consider several factors such as the game's theme, genre, and target audience. Here is a step-by-step approach to designing the main character:

1. Determine the game's theme and genre: Understand the overall concept and setting of the game. Is it a fantasy adventure, sci-fi exploration, or something else? This will help establish the visual style and characteristics of the main character.

2. Define the main character's role: Decide on the main character's purpose in the game. Are they a hero on a quest, a detective solving mysteries, or a scientist exploring new worlds? This will shape their abilities, skills, and appearance.

3. Create a backstory: Develop a backstory for the main character to give them depth and motivation. Consider their past experiences, personality traits, and any unique abilities or powers they may possess. This will make the character more relatable and engaging for players.

4. Design the appearance: Sketch or create concept art for the main character's appearance. Consider their physical attributes, such as gender, age, body type, and facial features. Also, think about their clothing, accessories, and any distinguishing marks or symbols that represent their role in the game.

5. Refine the character's personality: Define the main character's personality traits, strengths, and weaknesses. This will influence their interactions with other characters and the decisions they make throughout the game.

6. Test and iterate: Once the initial design is complete, gather feedback from the development team or potential players. Make adjustments based on the feedback to ensure the main character aligns with the game's vision and resonates with the target audience.

Next request.



AI User:

Instruction: Design a variety of challenging puzzles for the game.
Input: None



AI Assistant:

Solution: To design a variety of challenging puzzles for the game, we can follow these steps:

1. Determine the puzzle types: Decide on the types of puzzles that will be included in the game. Some common puzzle types include logic puzzles, riddles, pattern recognition, maze-solving, and object manipulation. Consider the game's theme and mechanics to ensure the puzzles align with the overall gameplay experience.

2. Establish difficulty levels: Determine the difficulty levels for the puzzles. Start with easier puzzles to introduce players to the mechanics and gradually increase the complexity as the game progresses. This will provide a sense of progression and keep players engaged.

3. Create clear objectives: Each puzzle should have a clear objective or goal for the player to achieve. Clearly communicate the objective to the player through visual cues, dialogue, or instructions. This will help players understand what they need to accomplish and provide a sense of direction.

4. Introduce new mechanics: Introduce new mechanics or elements with each puzzle to keep the gameplay fresh and challenging. For example, you can introduce new objects, tools, or abilities that players need to utilize to solve the puzzles. This will prevent the gameplay from becoming repetitive and maintain player interest.

5. Provide hints and feedback: Consider including hints or clues to assist players who may be struggling with a particular puzzle. These hints can be optional and gradually revealed to avoid giving away the solution too easily. Additionally, provide feedback to players when they make progress or solve a puzzle correctly. This feedback can be visual, auditory, or through in-game dialogue.

6. Playtest and iterate: Test the puzzles with a group of playtesters to gather feedback on their difficulty, clarity, and overall enjoyment. Make adjustments based on the feedback to ensure the puzzles are challenging yet solvable. Iterate on the puzzles to improve their design and flow.

Next request.



AI User:

Instruction: Design a visually stunning virtual world for the game.
Input: None



AI Assistant:

Solution: To design a visually stunning virtual world for the game, we can follow these steps:

1. Establish the overall theme and atmosphere: Determine the theme and atmosphere of the virtual world. Is it a lush fantasy forest, a futuristic cityscape, or a mysterious ancient temple? This will set the tone for the visuals and guide the design choices.

2. Create a diverse and detailed environment: Design a diverse range of environments within the virtual world, such as forests, mountains, caves, or underwater areas. Each environment should have unique features, landmarks, and elements that make them visually appealing and distinct.

3. Pay attention to lighting and ambiance: Lighting plays a crucial role in creating a visually stunning world. Experiment with different lighting techniques, such as dynamic lighting, volumetric lighting, and global illumination, to enhance the atmosphere and bring the virtual world to life. Consider the time of day, weather conditions, and the mood you want to convey.

4. Use high-quality textures and materials: Utilize high-resolution textures and materials to add detail and realism to the virtual world. Pay attention to the surfaces of objects, such as rocks, trees, water, and buildings, and ensure they are visually appealing and consistent with the overall theme.

5. Implement realistic particle effects: Incorporate particle effects, such as fire, smoke, water splashes, or falling leaves, to add dynamic elements and visual interest to the virtual world. These effects can enhance the immersion and make the world feel more alive.

6. Optimize performance: While striving for visual excellence, it's important to optimize the virtual world for performance. Implement techniques like level of detail (LOD) systems, occlusion culling, and efficient rendering algorithms to ensure smooth gameplay and prevent performance issues.

7. Iterate and polish: Continuously iterate on the virtual world's design, gathering feedback from the development team or potential players. Polish the visuals, making adjustments to lighting, textures, and effects to achieve the desired level of visual stunningness.

Next request.



AI User:

Instruction: Implement realistic physics simulations for the game.
Input: None



AI Assistant:

Solution: To implement realistic physics simulations for the game, we can follow these steps:

1. Choose a physics engine: Select a physics engine that suits the requirements of the game. There are several popular physics engines available, such as Unity's PhysX, Box2D, or Bullet Physics. Consider factors like ease of integration, performance, and the specific physics features needed for the game.

2. Define the physics properties: Determine the physics properties for the objects in the game. This includes attributes like mass, friction, restitution, and collision shapes. Assign appropriate values to ensure objects behave realistically when interacting with each other and the environment.

3. Implement collision detection: Set up collision detection between objects to ensure they interact realistically. This involves defining collision shapes for objects and detecting collisions based on their positions and shapes. Use the physics engine's collision detection functions or algorithms to handle these interactions accurately.

4. Apply forces and impulses: Use forces and impulses to simulate realistic movement and interactions. Apply forces like gravity, friction, or external forces to objects to make them respond naturally. Apply impulses to objects when they collide or interact with other objects to simulate realistic reactions.

5. Handle constraints and joints: Implement constraints and joints to simulate connections between objects. This can include constraints like hinges, springs, or ropes, which allow objects to move and interact in a physically accurate manner. Use the physics engine's constraint or joint systems to set up and manage these connections.

6. Test and refine: Continuously test the physics simulations in the game to ensure they behave as expected. Adjust the physics properties, forces, and constraints as needed to achieve the desired level of realism and gameplay experience. Gather feedback from playtesters to identify any issues or areas for improvement.

7. Optimize performance: Physics simulations can be computationally expensive, so it's important to optimize performance. Use techniques like spatial partitioning, collision culling, or reducing the number of physics calculations for objects that are far away or not in the player's immediate vicinity.

Next request.



AI User:

Instruction: Develop complex algorithms to render detailed 3D environments for the game.
Input: None



AI Assistant:

Solution: To develop complex algorithms to render detailed 3D environments for the game, we can follow these steps:

1. Choose a rendering framework or engine: Select a rendering framework or engine that supports the desired level of detail and complexity for the game's environments. Popular options include Unity, Unreal Engine, or custom-built rendering engines. Consider factors like ease of use, performance, and the specific rendering features needed for the game.

2. Implement level of detail (LOD) systems: LOD systems help manage the level of detail displayed based on the distance from the camera. Develop algorithms that dynamically adjust the level of detail for objects and textures to optimize performance while maintaining visual quality. This can involve techniques like mesh simplification, texture mipmapping, or impostors.

3. Utilize efficient culling techniques: Implement culling techniques to avoid rendering objects that are not visible to the camera. This can include frustum culling, occlusion culling, or portal-based culling. These techniques help improve performance by reducing the number of objects that need to be rendered.

4. Implement advanced shading and lighting models: Develop algorithms to support advanced shading and lighting models for realistic rendering. This can include techniques like physically based rendering (PBR), global illumination, or real-time reflections. These algorithms simulate the behavior of light and materials to create visually stunning and realistic environments.

5. Optimize rendering pipelines: Optimize the rendering pipelines to ensure efficient rendering of objects and textures. This can involve techniques like batching similar objects together, using GPU instancing, or implementing efficient texture streaming. These optimizations help improve performance and reduce rendering overhead.

6. Implement post-processing effects: Develop algorithms for post-processing effects to enhance the visual quality of the rendered environments. This can include effects like depth of field, motion blur, ambient occlusion, or color grading. These effects add depth and realism to the scenes and contribute to the overall visual appeal.

7. Test and iterate: Continuously test the rendering algorithms and environments to ensure they meet the desired level of detail and visual quality. Gather feedback from the development team or potential players and make adjustments as needed to improve performance or address any visual issues.

2. Implement input handling: Develop a system to handle player input, such as keyboard, mouse, or controller inputs. 6. Manage player progression: Develop a system to track and manage player progression through the game. This can include tracking completed interactions, unlocking new interactions or areas based on player achievements, or providing rewards for successful interactions. 5. Reward players for uncovering treasures: Design rewards for players who successfully uncover hidden treasures. These rewards can include in-game currency, unique items, character upgrades, or access to new areas. Rewards should be meaningful and provide a sense of accomplishment and progression.

6. Balance difficulty and accessibility: Ensure that the system for uncovering hidden treasures strikes a balance between difficulty and accessibility. The challenges should be challenging enough to engage players but not so difficult that they discourage exploration. Consider providing optional hints or difficulty settings to cater to different player preferences.

title: [Torii] Pad query values to there defined types if they are not correct
body:
The issue is that the torii requires queries to be submitted in a "padded" hexadecimal format. 

This format is not user-friendly and can be cumbersome to input. For instance, instead of simply inputting a number like 1234, users are required to enter a long string like '0x00000000000000000000000000000000b8c8c284efece3ed7caa915d58d1c239.

The suggested improvement is to allow users to input queries using a more human-readable format, such as plain integers (e.g., 1234), which would enhance the usability and accessibility of the system. 

Torii should automatically parse the inputs, format where needed and execute.

title: Enhance and Update the README File for Better Clarity and Engagement
body:
The README file is the first point of contact for many users and potential contributors to the Free API List with React project. While it currently provides a basic overview and instructions, it can be improved for better engagement, clarity, and thoroughness. This issue focuses on enhancing the README file to make it more informative, engaging, and user-friendly, thereby attracting more users and contributors.

Tasks:

Expand the Features section to include more details about each feature, potentially with screenshots or GIFs to visually showcase the project.
Update the Getting Started section with more detailed setup instructions, including any prerequisites and common troubleshooting steps.
Enhance the Contributing section with specific types of contributions that are welcome, such as code, documentation, design, etc., and a brief guide on how to get started with contributions.
Optionally, add a Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) section to address common queries.
Review the overall structure and readability of the README, ensuring that it is welcoming and informative for both users and potential contributors.
Skills Required:

Good writing and communication skills.
Basic understanding of Markdown for formatting.
Familiarity with the project to accurately describe its features and contribution process.
Good First Issue: Yes

Mentorship:
This task offers an excellent opportunity for contributors to enhance documentation skills and understand the project in-depth. We will provide guidance on effective README structure and content.

Additional Context:
A well-crafted README file can significantly impact the project's accessibility and attractiveness to new users and contributors. The goal is to create a README that is both informative and inviting.

Contributors are encouraged to ask questions and seek help in the issue comments. Our team is ready to assist and ensure a successful contribution experience!

title: Add Tooltip for Theme Toggle and Navigation Buttons in Header Component
body:
Our Header component includes a theme toggle switch and icon buttons for navigation but lacks tooltips, which can help users understand the purpose of these interactive elements. This beginner-friendly issue involves adding descriptive tooltips to the theme toggle and icon buttons in the Header component, improving the user interface by providing immediate visual feedback and enhancing accessibility.

Tasks:

Implement Tooltip components from Material-UI around the Switch and IconButton elements.
Create a tooltip for the theme toggle switch that indicates its function (e.g., "Switch to dark/light theme").
Add tooltips for the "Tools" and "Docs" icon buttons with appropriate descriptions (e.g., "Go to Tools", "View Documentation").
Ensure that tooltips are appropriately styled and positioned to match the current design aesthetics of the header.
Skills Required:

Basic understanding of React and Material-UI components
Knowledge of implementing accessible UI elements
Good First Issue: Yes

Mentorship:
This is a great opportunity for newcomers to dive into React and Material-UI's documentation and learn how to work with tooltips. We encourage asking questions and will provide guidance as needed.

Additional Resources:

[Material-UI Tooltips Documentation](https://mui.com/components/tooltips/)
[React Accessibility Guidelines](https://reactjs.org/docs/accessibility.html)
Contributors can discuss their approach and ask for help in the comments of this issue. Our team is here to support you in making your first contribution to our project!

title: Enhance Accessibility and Add Keyboard Navigation Support in Hero Component
body:
The Hero component is a key part of our project's user interface, offering an entry point to the different areas of our API directory. To ensure that our site is accessible to all users, including those with disabilities, we need to improve the accessibility of this component. Additionally, adding keyboard navigation support will make our website more user-friendly, especially for users who rely on keyboard-only navigation.

Tasks:

Ensure all interactive elements in the Hero component are accessible using the keyboard (Tab key navigation).
Add proper ARIA labels to the GitHub star button and the Docs button for screen reader users.
Implement focus styles for the buttons when they are navigated to using the keyboard.
Optional: Conduct a basic accessibility audit of the component using a tool like Lighthouse or axe Accessibility Checker.
Skills Required:

Familiarity with React and JavaScript
Basic understanding of web accessibility standards (WCAG)
Experience with or willingness to learn about ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) labels
Good First Issue: Yes

Mentorship:
We will provide guidance on how to approach accessibility issues and are available for questions anytime. Beginners are welcome as this is a great opportunity to learn about web accessibility.

Additional Resources:

[Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG)](https://www.w3.org/WAI/standards-guidelines/wcag/)
[Introduction to ARIA](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA)
[React Official Documentation on Accessibility](https://reactjs.org/docs/accessibility.html)
Feel free to ask questions and seek assistance in the issue comments if you are unsure about anything or need help getting started. We're here to support your contribution journey!

title: Merge 40 Historical Temperature Datasets for Climate-Resilient Agricultural Analysis
body: We aim to merge the 40 datasets comprising daily maximum and minimum temperatures from 1999 to 2018, facilitating comprehensive analysis for climate-resilient agricultural insights. Merging these datasets is crucial for streamlining data accessibility and enabling a unified analysis framework. This task involves merging corresponding daily maximum and minimum temperature datasets per year, aggregating weather station information, and organizing the data into a cohesive format. The merged dataset will serve as the foundation for developing predictive models, optimizing crop planting times, and enhancing agricultural resilience against climatic variations. Efficient merging ensures streamlined data processing and analysis for impactful climate-resilient agricultural strategies in Africa.

title: Language switch-er
body:
**Issue Title:** Implementation of Language Switch Feature

**Description:**

**Overview:**
This issue is created to track the implementation of a language switch feature in the application. Enabling users to switch between languages enhances accessibility and user experience, making the application more versatile.

**Objectives:**

1. **Requirements Gathering:**
   - Identify the languages to be supported.
   - Determine the scope of language switch functionality (e.g., for the entire application or specific sections).

2. **Integration with UI:**
   - Integrate language switch options seamlessly into the user interface.
   - Implement a clear and user-friendly way for users to select their preferred language.

3. **Language Files:**
   - Prepare language files or resources for each supported language.
   - Ensure that translations are accurate and culturally appropriate.

4. **Backend Implementation:**
   - Implement backend support for language selection.
   - Develop mechanisms to dynamically switch content based on the selected language.

5. **Persistence:**
   - Implement a mechanism to persist user language preferences across sessions.

6. **Testing:**
   - Conduct thorough testing to ensure that language switching works as expected.
   - Check for potential issues related to content overflow or display inconsistencies.

7. **Documentation:**
   - Update user documentation to include information on how to use the language switch feature.
   - Provide guidance for developers on maintaining language files.

8. **User Feedback:**
   - Collect user feedback on the language switch feature and make necessary adjustments.


**Dependencies:**

- Coordination with UI/UX designers for seamless integration.
- Collaboration with backend developers for system-level support.
- User testing and feedback collection.

**Additional Notes:**
Implementing a language switch feature is crucial for applications with a diverse user base. Regular communication within the development team and feedback collection from users will be essential for the success of this implementation.

For some guidance on how exactly to fix these, check out [this comment](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/36523#issuecomment-1819160512).

title: Tabbing through poi details opens and closes the collapsibles
body:
### Describe the Bug

<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->
If I am tabbing through the poi details, the collapsibles collapse and open seemingly randomly.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Go to https://webnext.integreat.app/testumgebung/de/locations/ballonfabrik
2. Tab until reaching "Kontaktdetails"
3. See collapsing
4. Tab some more forward/backwards to see more collapsing/opening

### Expected Behavior

<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->
The collapsibles should not open/close on tab. Instead, they should only open/close if another key is pressed.
Also, the whole button/collapsible header should have an accessibility label, not just the icon.

### Actual Behavior

<!-- A clear and concise description of what actually happened. -->
The collapsibles open/close on tab.

### Additional Information

<!-- Add any other context (e.g. logs, screenshots, environment etc.) about the problem here. -->

None.

- [X] I agree to follow activist's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/activist-org/activist/blob/main/.github/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

### Description

We have the component [GridFilterTags](https://github.com/activist-org/activist/blob/main/frontend/components/grid/GridFilterTags.vue) that provides tags for filtering search and page results. We as of now don't have styling added for when one of the options is selected. Potentially look into refactoring this component with a Headless UI component like [radio group](https://headlessui.com/vue/radio-group) would be good to achieve this, but we'd also need to make sure that we allow for selecting more than one option and also deselecting an option.

### Contribution

Happy to support with this or get to it myself eventually! This is a great `good first issue` for someone wanting to contribute to activist for the first time, and is of course open for those already in the contributor base. 

Let's first discuss the implementation and then we can go from there! 🚀

title: Enhance Settings and UI in Password Manager
body:
### Description
The goal of this update is to enhance the user experience in the Password Manager application. The specific changes are:

1. **Settings Sync:** Implement synchronization of all application settings with `chrome.sync.storage` for a consistent user experience across devices.

2. **Button Placement:** Relocate the password generator button from the bottom to the top of the interface to improve accessibility and user convenience.

### Additional Details
- **Testing Steps:**
  - Verify that all settings are synchronized correctly.
  - Test the new placement of the password generator button for accessibility.
  - Evaluate the overall UI improvements and ensure code quality enhancements.

### Expected Behavior
Users should experience improved settings synchronization, easier access to the password generator button, and an enhanced overall UI.

title: Using assistant settings to launch system only/privileged components
body:
### Please check before submitting an issue

- [X] I am using the latest version of App Manager
- [X] I have searched the issues and haven't found anything relevant
- [X] I have read the docs

### Describe a description of the new feature

The secure setting found in the android settings database can allow for launching of any system only component.


Example using com.android.settings/.password.ChooseLockPattern

adb exec-out settings put secure assistant com.android.settings/.password.ChooseLockPattern
adb exec-out input keyevent 219



### Describe the solution you'd like

Step By Step
1. Check App Manager has Accessibility Perms
2. Store secure assistant setting
3. Store Component to be launched into secure assistant setting.
4. Use Accessibility to send KEYCODE_ASSIST (219)
5. Restore secure assistant setting to original value

### Describe alternatives you've considered

this could also be done via adb mode.
but with the android.permission.WRITE_SECURE_SETTINGS it could be done in "No Root" mode.

### Additional context

Works since API 16, Works Across Vendors As Well
Personally only tested down to API 20, and on Google, Redmi, Motorola, and Samsung devices.

Google Pixel 6a
Redmi Note 7
Samsung Note 8
Motorola G Stylus
Some Random Android Desk Phone running 4.4W

title: Group Configurations in fieldset where possible
body:
# Feature Request

## Description
Wrap the slider configurations (e.g. Model Temperature header, slider & info button) in a fieldset so that they are programmatically linked. Remove any duplicate labels that are not needed anymore. 
Style the element so that there is no visual difference compared to before (the fieldset element will automatically add a border, that can be removed). 

This might be possible with other configurations as well, but with the slider configs it should pretty straightforward. 

## Screenshots
Fieldset adds a border, remove this so that it looks as it did before
![Image](https://github.com/ScottLogic/prompt-injection/assets/125262707/c24e2610-b1f7-4f55-91ba-7b99dfdcd2a1)

## Additional context
Accessibility improvement to reduce noise in the accessibility tree and correctly link related inputs together

## Acceptance criteria
**GIVEN** a user navigates the configurations with assistive tech
**WHEN** they move through one section of the configurations
**THEN** the interactive elements are grouped and labels aren't repeated unnecessarily
